SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

test.policies
Class XacmlPolicyBuilder

java.lang.Object
  test.policies.XacmlPolicyBuilder

public class XacmlPolicyBuilder
extends java.lang.Object

This is an adaptation of the sunxacml SamplePolicyBuilder to build some policies to use with the TestAzApi OpenAz test program. The original class was copied as is, renamed, and then modified where necessary to achieve the desired policies.

This class may be used as a template for policy-building, at least for policies that do not have complex conditions. Currently, this class uses a simple paradigm that contains a template for Match functions, which refer to an attribute in the context and compare it to a local value in the Match function. i.e. ActionMatch, ResourceMatch, SubjectMatch. Environment attrs only can be ref'd in Conditions, because sunxacml implements XACML 1.1, which does not all Environment in the Target.

The basic recursive structure is initiated in the method called from main: 

 
                buildPolicySet(PolicySetEnum, PolicySetEnum)

Each of these methods constructs a series of Match expressions which are used to identify attributes and a match condition to apply to the attribute. In the case of Obligations, there is no condition to apply to the attribute so the MatchId is null.

This is an example program that shows how to build and generate an XACML Policy. This doesn't show all the available features, but it provides a good sample of commonly used functionality. Note that there's a fair amount of duplicate code in this class, since verbosity (in this case) makes the code a little easier to understand. An equivalent Policy to that generated here is found in the policy directory as generated.xml. The generated request can be used with this policy.

The Policy primarily uses the "OR" function to create disjoint groupings that can be incorporated to one Policy. They could also be put in a separate policies in a PolicySet (need to test), but the underlying constraint in sunxacml is that only one Policy may be "applicable". This is sensible assuming that this is the top level PDP that makes the final decision. However, it is not clear yet if this has any practical restrictions on how policies may be defined when they are part of PolicySets, etc. i.e. is the constraint really that only one "PolicySet" may be applicable? If so, then this would be ok.

Since:
1.1
Author:
seth proctor, rich levinson

functionId - the matching function identifier

value - the AttributeValue used in this match

createTargetAttributeMatchList

public static java.util.List createTargetAttributeMatchList(AttributeMatchExpression[] targetMatchDesignators)
                                                     throws java.net.URISyntaxException
Creates a Target Attribute Match section (subject, resource, action) to be added to one of the collections in the Target element. Since ultimately all the attribute values that are in here will need to be converted to or from string along the way, this method is for convenience to just provide strings as args and let it load the URIs.

This method does the inner "AND" loop when multiple attribute expressions are defined.

Also, the main thing it is doing internally is dispatching on the type of AttributeValue that needs to be created based on attributeDataType, and it creates that AttributeValue from the string passed in.

This method may not be usable for all DataTypes, and it relies on the user to know what combos are acceptable, although that type of checking could be added later.

It is assumed for now that the AttributeDesignatorExpression can be defined to contain all the info necessary to do a match or comparison of a request attribute to some value defined in the policy, which is the attr value held in the AttributeDesignatorExpression. For now, assume we can do: =, %lt;, >, and that the 2-d array of attrDesExp can infer an inner "AND" and an outer "OR" for a particular defn of some target collection of entities.

Parameters:
targetMatchDesignators - an array of AttributeMatchExpressions each of which contains all the info necessary to evaluate an expresssion
Returns:
targetAttributeMatch a List of attribute matches that will be ANDed when put in the Policy.
Throws:
java.net.URISyntaxException

public static java.util.List createObligationAttributeList(AttributeMatchExpression[] targetMatchDesignators)
                                                    throws java.net.URISyntaxException
Create a set of AttributeAssignments for Obligations

targetMatchDesignators -
Returns:
a List of
Throws:
java.net.URISyntaxException

createRuleCondition

public static com.sun.xacml.cond.Apply createRuleCondition(AttributeMatchExpression[] tmd)
                                                    throws java.net.URISyntaxException
Creates the Condition used in the Rule. Note that a Condition is just a special kind of Apply.

Also, this condition only will work with a limited set of functions, in particular it is the same as the match functions (an attribute designator plus a comparator) except that it applies the one and only function to the attribute designator, which is implicitly performed by the match functions. However this is more limited than match since match will go thru a list of values and return true when and if it finds a match. This will only allow one and only one value to be in the list.

Returns:
the condition
Throws:
java.net.URISyntaxException - if there is a problem with any of the URIs

createTargetPolicyOrRule

public static com.sun.xacml.Target createTargetPolicyOrRule(AttributeMatchExpression[][] attrSubMatchExprs,
                                                            AttributeMatchExpression[][] attrResMatchExprs,
                                                            AttributeMatchExpression[][] attrActMatchExprs,
                                                            java.lang.Enum targetEnum)
                                                     throws java.net.URISyntaxException
Creates the Target used by Policy or Rules.

Passed 2-d arrays of AttributeDesignatorExpression[][]

Left index is outer "OR" of entities Right index is inner "AND" of entities

Note: for xacml 1.1 distinction between empty and null is used such that null produces , etc. whereas empty produces , where latter means no actions supported in xacml 1.1, but means any action supported in xacml 2.0.

Returns:
the target
Throws:
java.net.URISyntaxException - if there is a problem with any of the URIs

logAttributeMatchExpression

public static void logAttributeMatchExpression(AttributeMatchExpression ame,
                                               int i)
This module processes one Attribute including its attributeId, its value, and other metadata. The point is to put the info out in an easy to read format. However, this is really to print what we have got, there will be corresponding modules to parse strings similar to what we are putting out, so these outputs represent analysis of the reqts for what will make effective input formats.

Parameters:
ame -
i -

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)

Command-line routine that bundles together all the information needed to create a Policy and then encodes the Policy, printing to standard out. To get usable input, set traceEnabled = false
